title: There is evidence that the mind is the product of a brain. There is not evidence that the mind is immaterial.

author: hammiesink
text:
Physical interaction seems to not be a very good argument, as even dualism is sometimes called "interactionism": the mind affects the body and the body affects the mind. Affecting a part of the body, such as a toe or your brain, causes mental events (like pain, or memory loss). But mental events can affect the body as well, such as a fear of burglars (a mental event) causing your hand to turn the lock. In other words, dualists fully acknowledge that you can affect the mind by affecting the body.

The primary reasons for thinking the mind cannot be explained by "just particles" are the peculiar properties it has, such as "aboutness." A mental event like a belief is *about* something. A belief *about* Paris. Or a fear *of* burglars. A mental event "points to" an object. But there is no such property in physics. What are electrons about? What are bosons about? What does a quark "point to?" It's clearly absurd to speak of this property in physics. So what exactly is the *physical* mechanism to suddenly have "aboutness" by...what...just having more particles? Using *only* the language of physics, what physical law says "when such and such number of particles are together in this exact way, they are about things."

author: InvisibleElves
text:
>Physical interaction seems to not be a very good argument, as even dualism is sometimes called "interactionism": the mind affects the body and the body affects the mind.

It’s not just interaction. Thoughts are physically transmitted. They are physically detectable.


>But mental events can affect the body as well, such as a fear of burglars (a mental event) causing your hand to turn the lock.

Fear of burglars can be physically removed from your brain.

By what mechanism do you think a mental state affects the brain? Is there something non-physical that has a direct effect on the physical motions of the brain, violating the laws of physics (inertia, conservation of matter and energy)?


>In other words, dualists fully acknowledge that you can affect the mind by affecting the body.

What aspect of the mind cannot be physically affected? Some aspect must belong to the non-physical.


>The primary reasons for thinking the mind cannot be explained by "just particles" are the peculiar properties it has, such as "aboutness."

>What are electrons about? What are bosons about? What does a quark "point to?"

[Fallacy of Composition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fallacy_of_composition).

There are many properties that groups of particles can have that the individual particles do not. Particles don’t have wetness, but put a few H20s together and you have it. Particles aren’t alive, but throw a few together and you get a tree. A computer has a kind of aboutness. Besides, aboutness is likely just an abstract category.

 
Just because we lack a complete physical explanation for a thing doesn’t mean it’s non-physical.

author: hammiesink
text:
>Thoughts are physically transmitted. They are physically detectable.

Correction: electrical activity *associated with* thoughts are physically detectable. But correlation <> identity; smoke is not fire.

>Is there something non-physical that has a direct effect on the physical motions of the brain, violating the laws of physics

Only if you think all causation must be "particles knocking into other particles." That indeed is part of the problem. Causation is a broader phenomenon than that. For example, creating more money causes inflation, but that is not a "particles bumping" causation.

>Particles don’t have wetness

But phenomena like "wetness" is just an example of stickiness, which is a relationship that can be described physically pretty easily: particles can stuck to other particles.

But an aboutness relationship cannot be described physically. For example, you can think about a perpetual motion machine. So there is a relationship between your thoughts (supposedly physical activity in your brain) and *an object that does not even exist.* You cannot describe such a relationship physically: object A is related to non-existent object B...? Doesn't work.

>A computer has a kind of aboutness.

Yes, endowed so by us. Without us around to declare that the word "DOG" on a monitor has a relationship with our small carnivore friends, it's just a bunch of meaningless glowing electrons that has *no* relationship whatsoever to the animal.

author: InvisibleElves
text:
>Correction: electrical activity associated with thoughts are physically detectable.

Enough electrical activity to reproduce the thought at the receiving end. The brain activity contains the entire thought.


>Is there something non-physical that has a direct effect on the physical motions of the brain, violating the laws of physics

>>Only if you think all causation must be "particles knocking into other particles." That indeed is part of the problem.

So yes? Something in excess of inertia and conservation of mass and energy is acting on brains, causing physical changes?


>Causation is a broader phenomenon than that. For example, creating more money causes inflation, but that is not a "particles bumping" causation.

That’s just a lot of “particles bumping” (or physics, which is more than just bumping particles).

>But phenomena like "wetness" is just an example of stickiness, which is a relationship that can be described physically pretty easily: particles can stuck to other particles.

Individual particles (even pairs of particles) do not stick together in the same way, much less produce wetness.


>But an aboutness relationship cannot be described physically. For example, you can think about a perpetual motion machine. So there is a relationship between your thoughts (supposedly physical activity in your brain) and an object that does not even exist.

The object of “aboutness” is not actually part of the relationship. It’s merely the concept of the object. It’s no different than a computer containing a model of a dragon. That doesn’t make the computer immaterial.


>A computer has a kind of aboutness.

>>Yes, endowed so by us. Without us around to declare that the word "DOG" on a monitor has a relationship with our small carnivore friends,

But one file or process can point to another, or use another as reference, or produce a particular output. They have aboutness as much as we do, just likely without the awareness of it.

author: InvisibleElves
text:
>Enough electrical activity to reproduce the thought at the receiving end.

>>Perhaps, but that's the issue that has been in debate for hundreds of years, and it's still quite a live one.

Just saying the debate is going on is not an argument.

The clearest example from the post is the complete, physical thought transmission between the Hogan twins, but partial reconstruction of thought has been done by machine.

>"Inflation" is not "particles moving away from" "creation of more money," as it would be if it were an example of particles bumping causation.

If you don’t assume that the minds involved are immaterial, then inflation is just a lot of complex physics. It’s like the weather: there are too many factors to account for, but they are all physical (“particles bumping”).

>Causation is much broader than just bumping and moving away from.

Yes, “particles bumping” is an extreme oversimplification of physics.


>Sure, but its easy to explain stickiness in physical terms.

So because it’s currently difficult to explain the mind in physics terms, that is evidence of dualism? Reads like an argument from ignorance.

All of chemistry is not easily explained by particle behavior.

>There is definitely a relationship between a thought and the object of thought, otherwise it just wouldn't be an object of thought.

It’s the same as the relationship between a computer model and the thing it’s modeling. There is a representation of similarity, but no magic connection to the thing being modeled (whether it exists outside the model or not). Aboutness has no effect on the thing it’s about, only on the model.

>They are just electrons. They have no meaning apart from intelligent creatures pointing to them and assigning them meaning.

They have aboutness, in that they “point” to other things.

author: hammiesink
text:
>why would it have to be a property of physics?

Because you don't want dualism to be true.

>Physics doesn't have a property of living/dead

But such a concept can be broken down into physical terms. Aboutness is peculiar, because it's a relationship between two things that literally have no physical relationship. If I think ABOUT Jupiter, there is my thought (thing 1), and the object of my thought (thing 2), so there is clearly a relationship between them. But it is not physical. Is there some kind of beam shooting out of my head connecting my thought to Jupiter? No.

What if I think about atoms *in general*, as a concept, not this or that specific atom. Well, now there is my thought (thing 1) and the object of my thought (every atom that has ever existed or will ever exist). There clearly isn't a physical relationship between thing 1 and literally every atom. Is a beam shooting out of my head and touching every atom in the past, present and future? That's silly. So, no, you cannot break "aboutness" down into physical terms.

author: The-Last-American
text:
> the mind affects the body and the body affects the mind

Correct, because they’re both physical.

> But mental events can affect the body as well

Correct, because they’re both physical.

> such as "aboutness." A mental event like a belief is about something.

This is a terrible concept, poorly defined (to be generous), with little to no value—certainly in this discussion—, and even what little value proponents try to eke from it are redundancies at best, or obfuscations at worst. If you wish to refer to the intentionality aspect of “aboutness”, then discuss intentionality, if you wish to discuss the concept of just “things being associated with other things”, then what you wish to engage in is a matter of interpretation about yet more ill-defined, squishy concepts.

> A mental event "points to" an object. But there is no such property in physics.

Says who? And what kind of connection or lack of connection do you think you’re making here, exactly? Are you saying you don’t believe that the brain is capable of forming associations? Are you saying it’s impossible for these associations to be physically measured? Incorrect on all fronts. The evolutionary path of these connections can also be traced back to the earliest forms of life, as could the concept—even a physically measurable one—of a “fear of burglars”.

The mere existence of abstract connections being made in the brain has nothing to do whether or not the medium in which it is happening is physical. It is. How do we know? Because we can literally measure it with physical instruments.

author: S1rmunchalot
text:
This is third order thinking which is an evolutionary advantage not unique to humans, is the suggestion that animals have 'souls'?.

If this, then that, memory formation and contextual retrieval,  experiential learning. Planning. Mental time travel. Deductive reasoning. Empathy. They all come out of this pre-frontal cortex expansion of the ability for abstract thinking. Morphology affects activity.

It is common to all tool makers and tool users to greater or lesser extents, some of whom aren't even primates let alone human.

In order to select, or design and make, a tool you have to have the ability to be able to hold an abstract idea of what you intend to achieve in your mind, how you intend to use that finished object or the steps you are going to take to make that object using the skills and tools you have access to. The more you use this skill, the more your survival depends upon it, the more often it will have selection bias and thus evolutionary pressure to reproduce that trait and improve on it.

This 'aboutness' argument is unscientific and spurious. Of course you affect the mind by affecting the body, because the self aware brain knows it cannot survive without the body so it is intrinsic to the brain to protect the body. We have evolved material biological systems to do just that, it is indeed a feedback loop.

author: hammiesink
text:
I didn't say anything about souls.

>This 'aboutness' argument is unscientific and spurious.

It's not a scientific argument; it's a philosophical one. The "aboutness" relationship cannot be explained physically. Try to explain another relationship, such as digestion, physically: it involves a clump of matter (physical things can be related by being "stuck together") that then breaks down (physical things can be described as "coming apart"). But the "aboutness" relationship cannot be described physically like that. An aboutness relationship could be between one event (your thought of perpetual motion objects) and an object *that doesn't even exist.* You cannot describe a relationship between a physical event and an object that doesn't exist in physical terms.

author: The-Last-American
text:
> The "aboutness" relationship cannot be explained physically.

This is because it is not a concept that concerns physical reality. I can’t measure my lawn with hopes and dreams, but I’ll be damned if neighbors’ dogs don’t make their way to physically defecating on it anyway.

> You cannot describe a relationship between a physical event and an object that doesn't exist in physical terms.

Are you trying to refer to abstract thought? Under what evidence do you have that abstract thoughts are not physical? How do you explain the ability to observe the brain engaging in abstract thought if these are not physical? If your argument is supposed to be “but these concepts cannot be translated into physical measurements”, then there would appear to be an inability to understand the difference between reality and imagination, and that being unable to physically measure the size of a lily from your mind doesn’t mean that the mind is therefore not comprised of physical reality, nor does that make the thought itself not a physical event.

The quote above is simply not true in any context anyway. You can absolutely “describe a relationship” between a physical event and the thought of an object, and you can do so in numerous ways. You can describe a relationship in terms of electromagnetic waves or even energy output and input, and the ways in which we can describe these physical relationships is increasing as our knowledge grows.

If you wish to make some kind of argument that physics cannot somehow describe ontology, then you aren’t even really making an argument, you’re just engaging in some form of weird philosophical fanfic.

author: InvisibleElves
hammiesink
text:
>It’s no different (in this regard) than a computer having a model of something otherwise not real.

Computers do not have models of things at all, real or not. What they have are glowing electrons that we *assign* meaning to. It's no different than an abacus. Does the first column of beads "point to" the concept of "ones?" Sure, but only because *we intelligent beings point to the beads and assign that meaning to them!* Apart from us, the first column of an abacus wouldn't mean "ones" anymore than it means "pizza" or "sharks." They are inert beads. They have no meaning. We just point to them and say "henceforth, these beads represent the ones digits." All computers do is put you in an infinite loop. If you need an intelligent being to get your aboutness, then you have to explain how that being's thoughts have aboutness, which means there must be some super being pointing to the neurons in their head and assigning meaning to them, which means there must be a superduper being pointing to the neurons in *their* head and assigning meaning, ad infinitum.

author: S1rmunchalot
text: Yes you can, that is the whole point of abstract thinking, it is not tied to merely the 'real world'. It includes the constructs in the mind, the reason we make those constructs is to try and make sense of the world around us, so that we can forward plan, we extrapolate. The mind world is the causative factor here, we have evolved to experience everything through this filter because we are not merely a collection of physical stimuli / response patterns. There is nothing mystical about it, and we see the evolution of it in many species to one degree or another.

author: hammiesink
text: This is not an objection. So there is a *relationship* between a thought in your mind…and an object that does not exist. This type of relationship cannot be described physically, since then there would have to be a relationship between two physical objects, the second object being non-existent and so therefore not a physical object. Contradictory.

author: S1rmunchalot
text:
>This type of relationship cannot be described physically

It is not at all contradictory. Yes it can be described physically.

The memory of an object is stored as chemicals in the neurons in the brain, the brain doesn't classify anything as 'physically real' and 'not physically real' in exactly the same way that a computer doesn't specify whether it is holding a 3D model of an item scanned from the real world or a hand made object in a 3D modelling program.

Because of the way the brain works anything you encounter is perceived through the memory of it - you create a memory  of something before you are even consciously aware of it and therefore you create your own perception of it, even if it is still physically causing a human interface response, ie something hot in the hand.

The pathway links between other neurons are also stored. It is a physical thing. you can lose memories over time, with disease, with drugs and with trauma both physical and psychological. Without a memory (chemicals stored in neurons) of something there is no human relationship with it. A brain surgeon knows that when he is going trough brain tissue to access other brain tissue he is potentially destroying memories.

We can give drugs that affect memory, prevent memory formation, indeed we do this many thousands of times per day when we give anaesthetics. I could read the whole bible to you in the initial recovery phase after a general anaesthetic and  according to a judeo-christian theist you have now been informed of 'the truth', yet I know you will have no memory of it after your next sleep period. Without that memory you cannot form an abstraction of a deity. A drug is merely atoms arranged a certain way that interact with other atoms in the cells of the brain... they are physical.
